results.title: Dissonant particles
results.brief_description:
An abstract animation based on experiments with sound. Gordon describes the work as follows “Psychoacoustic experiments have indicated that two pure sine tones are played simultaneously, they will sound most dissonant when they are around a semitone apart in pitch. In Dissonant Particles, each particle emits a sine tone. The dissonance between them acts as a repulsive force that pushes the particles apart, both in position and in pitch. There is also a long-range (“cosmological”) attractive force that prevents the particles from flying off to infinity. The particles pulsate and slowly evaporate; both of these processes affect the way they “feel” the forces acting on them. The colour of a particle indicates pitch: red for low pitches, green for intermediate, and blue for high. The camera tracks one particle, which is always shown in the centre of the screen.”
Psycho acoustics is the study of subjective experience of audio versus the scientific measurement of sound by various devices. For example, the frequency of a signal may not change but we may perceive pitch changes if the amplitude changes.
http://www.gordonmonro.com/pieces/dissparticles.html

group_siblings.title: Telestreet: the Italian Media Jacking Movement

results.title: Telestreet: the Italian Media Jacking Movement
results.brief_description: “Telestreet” is a network of pirate micro TV transmitters set up by media activists across Italy. Since beginning in June 2002 there are now almost 200 stations throughout the country. This documentary contains interviews with some of those media activists.

results.title: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive
results.brief_description: Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koori Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

constellations_primary.name: Connecting through film
constellations_primary.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

results.title_for_label: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive
results.description:
Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

“When we talk about Traditional Aboriginal knowledge in Victoria we need to remember it is one of the oldest living forms of communication in the world. It continues today as one of the main mediums through which cultural knowledge and story lines are passed on. The images you will see in this exhibition reflect the value and importance of oral knowledge as an ongoing and vibrant cultural link with the past.” - Dr Wayne Atkinson senior Yorta Yorta Elder and creator of the Koorie Oral History Program
description_for_label:
Koorie people record ourselves as a means of self-representation, to destroy stereotypes and to ensure that we are not erased. These films from the Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive preserve our culture and kinship for future generations.

results.title: Bitter Herbs and Honey
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Amber Films
results.brief_description: Australian documentary focuses on the lives of European Jews who settled in the Melbourne suburb of Carlton in the 1940s, fleeing World War II atrocities and post-War conditions. Interestingly the Jews from Eastern Europe clashed with Anglo-Jews, settled in the nineteenth century, who identified as British rather than Jewish and disapproved of the too obvious presence of Sephardic Jews, with whom they feared association. Despite these and other difficulties, social groups thrived in the suburb, where people shared life, food, religion and a common experience. Local residents from the period, many recalling their childhood, discuss a marvellously rich and joyous, if impoverished, family life; others talk about the racism suffered at school and in the street; several recount the pain of being a Holocaust survivor and the trials of assimilation. Includes archival footage from the era interspersed with recreations and a slew of interviews that include: Pinchus Ringelblum, Hilary Rubinstein, Bernard Rechter, Solomon Pose, Victor Smorgon, Arnord Zable, Jean Holkner, June Factor, Freydi Mrocki, Sam Lipski, Amirah Inglis, Rachel Levita and Miriam Kuna. Features some marvellous Yiddish songs and several interviewees discuss their parents yearning to sustain the use of Yiddish language. With occasional English subtitles.

results.title: 9.5mm Pathé-Baby camera and projector
results.brief_description: The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations.

constellations_primary.name: 9.5mm Pathe-Baby and parents behaving badly
constellations_primary.description: A look at the link between the Pathé-Baby system and animation, as well as the relationship between cinematic parents and their children.

results.description:
The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations. This unique film width made it easy to duplicate commercial films for home use, and the hand-cranked projector took up to 60 feet of film.

The portability and simplicity of the Pathé-Baby made the system widely popular internationally. This one was used by pioneering Australian aviator John Robertson Duigan MC to document early aviation and his home life. Having built the first Australian-made aircraft, Duigan definitely had something worth capturing.
description_for_label:
The Pathé-Baby camera and projector was an inexpensive and easy-to-use amateur film system introduced in 1922. It used 9.5mm film with central perforations. This unique film width made it easy to duplicate commercial films for home use, and the hand-cranked projector took up to 60 feet of film.

The portability and simplicity of the Pathé-Baby made the system widely popular internationally. This one was used by pioneering Australian aviator John Robertson Duigan MC to document early aviation and his home life. Having built the first Australian-made aircraft, Duigan definitely had something worth capturing.
